title: Nutrien in potash warning to BHP and gas price lament
text:
“Right now the greenfields economics for potash plants even in Canada, they don’t make economic sense,” he said.

“When we look at a greenfields mine in western Canada, the conclusion that we come to .... is that the rate of return is extremely low right now and that is even with a fairly significant increase in global potash prices.

“I think that for the next decade or two what is going to happen is that the incumbents are going to find a way to put brownfields tonnes into the market at much lower cost as demand continues to grow.

Risky proposition

"So if you are sitting there trying to make a decision on greenfields investment when you know that there is currently excess capacity plus there is brownfields expansion opportunities, that is a risky proposition."

Mr Magro said Nutrien would like to produce nitrogen fertiliser in Australia but gas prices were too high to justify such an investment.

Nutrien has also looked at phosphate options, but again considered costs of production too high.

However, Mr Magro said an investment in production assets was the next logical step for Nutrien after the $469 million Ruralco acquisition and its 2017 purchase of the Louis Dreyfus fertiliser storage and distribution assets in Australia.

Advertisement

“The next logical step for the value chain would be production. The opportunity is there but every time we have looked, we haven’t been able to meet our economic and our strategic hurdles in Australia,” he said.

Mr Magro’s comments suggested Nutrien had cast an eye over Incitec Pivot’s fertiliser production assets, which include heavy manufacturing at Gibson Island and the Duchess ammonia phosphate mine in western Queensland as well as east coast blending facilities.

“Given the timelines that I understand that acquisition is under, it is not something we are actively looking at right now,” he said.

Incitec chief executive Jeanne Johns has flagged a possible divestment of the Australian fertiliser business that would allow the company to focus on its explosives division.

Tempted by opportunity

Mr Magro said Nutrien would never say never to building or buying production assets in Australia and would be highly tempted by an opportunity in nitrogen if it could find low-cost gas.

"In nitrogen we need low-cost gas. It is 70-75 per cent of the cost structure," he said.

"Relatively speaking gas in Australia is expensive and I think that is why you don't have a strong nitrogen business that is export based.

Advertisement

"But you have a very strong LNG business and I think certain trade-offs have been made and by the looks of it for the right reasons. Whereas in Canada decisions were made decades ago to have a petrochemical and fertiliser production business based on low-cost gas."

Nutrien is set to scrap the Landmark and Ruralco brand names as it focuses on an integration of the two businesses which will leave ASX-listed Elders a long way back as the second biggest player in farm services in Australia.
description: Canadian fertiliser giant questions the wisdom of $US5b Jansen project and reveals only high gas prices have stopped it building or buying production assets in Australia.
